title: Mentorship Session
session-info:
The ISME Early Career Scientist Committee recognizes the growing need for mentorship within our scientific community. As such, during registration, people were offered the opportunity to identify as a potential mentor or mentee for the ISME19 conference in Cape Town (18-23 August 2024). The ISME19 Mentoring Program will provide small group matches between mentors (mid to late career ISME19 attendees) with mentees (students, early career professionals, and first-time ISME19 attendees) and offer an orientation on the first day of the program. The purpose? To help student and early career participants benefit from the insights and guidance of “more experienced” ISME members.

While mentoring can be an extended relationship, our focus for ISME19 is the conference experience. In addition to small group mentoring, ISME19 will offer unique opportunities for mentors and mentees to share time together and an orientation to help first time attendees make the most of the conference. This mentorship program is paired with the rollout of an Early Career Scientist forum hosted on Discord where we aim to build a community of resources for ECSs and interactions with more senior microbial ecologists.

Description of the activities at ISME19
On Sunday 18 August at 2pm in Ballroom West, just before the congress opening ceremony, the ECSC will run an introduction session for the ISME19 mentoring program, including introducing the ECSC's Discord platform to encourage ongoing communication and networking. Mentees will have the opportunity to meet their mentors face-to-face, creating meaningful connections over casual conversations. The event will conclude with a Q&A session to clarify any remaining questions and ensure that participants are well-prepared for their mentorship journey.
Show More

title: Meet the Editors
session-info:
ISME Publications invites Early Career Researchers to meet the editors and the publisher of The ISME Journal and ISME Communications. Meet them for a drink on the 27th floor of the Hotel Sky, Cape Town, just across the street from the CTICC. Or come to enjoy the view.

This is your chance to have an informal chat to the ISME senior editors, and ask them anything you want about publishing and writing.

This event will start at 20.15 and end around 21.30.

title: Winogradsky Award Presentation - Jennifer Martiny
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Phil Hugenholtz, Australia
Jennifer Martiny is the first winner of the Winogradsky Award, the newly developed award for mid-career scientists who have substantially advanced the field of microbial ecology.

She is an exceptional researcher in microbial ecology and biogeography, whose groundbreaking work has significantly advanced our understanding of microbial diversity and its impact on ecosystem functioning. Her research explores the origins and maintenance of microbial diversity, leveraging innovative methodologies to reveal how selection, dispersal, drift, and diversification shape bacterial and fungal community assembly. Some of her key contributions include insights into how ecological and evolutionary processes simultaneously influence the assembly and functioning of microbial communities and the development of tractable microbial systems to explore eco-evolutionary processes in natural settings, especially in the context of rapid global change.
Show More
Presentation

Eco-evolutionary processes of assembly in wild microbial communities
Jennifer Martiny, University of California, Irvine, United States

Session Leaders

title: Omics in microbial ecology: big data, big opportunities, big pitfalls
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: A. Murat Eren, Germany
Chair: Mihaela Pertea, United States
Microbial ecology is living its golden age as massive data streams from molecular approaches that typically end with 'omics offer detailed snapshots of microbial life from all ecosystems of our planet. This unprecedented access to data demands microbial ecologists to find their way in complex datasets through emerging computational strategies, and orchestrate them to form and test hypotheses by typically integrating heterogeneous sources of data. Our field has made remarkable strides towards a better understanding of microbial ecology and evolution thanks to the insights afforded by big data. However, dealing with complex datasets brings its own challenges that can also lead to various undesirable outcomes that span from underutilization of data to overinterpretation of findings. Our session aims to bring together experts of computation and microbial ecology to demonstrate applications of integrated ‘omics strategies to address contemporary questions of microbiology, and foster a dialogue between the speakers and attendees through best practices in data analysis, integration, and interpretation.

title: Agricultural microbiomes
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Karin Jacobs, South Africa
Chair: Brajesh Singh, Australia
The microbiome play critical role in ecosystem function in all habitats. In agriculture, the contribution of the microbiome to food production has been recognised in the last few years, and increasingly researchers are investigating these communities to understand processes such as disease suppression, nutrient cycling, carbon sequestration and plant growth promotion as well as the use of these organisms as biofertilizers and biopesticides. This session aims to highlight progress made in understanding the complex contribution of microorganisms to the sustainable production of food, and creation of a healthier environment.

title: Peer Review and Publishing in ISME Journals
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Josh D. Neufeld, Canada
Society-owned journals play a pivotal role in shaping the future of scientific publishing. In this panel discussion, we will discuss peer review and publishing in The ISME Journal and ISME Communications. The Editors-in-Chief of the journals
will introduce new publishing plans implemented after moving to Oxford University Press and share advice for manuscript preparation. We will announce the Early Career Scientist Reviewer initiative, which will promote inclusion of early career
researchers in the peer review process of the ISME journals. Oxford University Press will also present the opportunities available to microbial ecologists. This panel discussion will enable a discussion about scientific writing and peer review and
target all microbial ecologists.

title: Agricultural microbiomes
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Karin Jacobs, South Africa
Chair: Brajesh Singh, Australia
The microbiome play critical role in ecosystem function in all habitats. In agriculture, the contribution of the microbiome to food production has been recognised in the last few years, and increasingly researchers are investigating these communities to understand processes such as disease suppression, nutrient cycling, carbon sequestration and plant growth promotion as well as the use of these organisms as biofertilizers and biopesticides. This session aims to highlight progress made in understanding the complex contribution of microorganisms to the sustainable production of food, and creation of a healthier environment.

title: Omics in microbial ecology: big data, big opportunities, big pitfalls
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: A. Murat Eren, Germany
Chair: Mihaela Pertea, United States
Microbial ecology is living its golden age as massive data streams from molecular approaches that typically end with 'omics offer detailed snapshots of microbial life from all ecosystems of our planet. This unprecedented access to data demands microbial ecologists to find their way in complex datasets through emerging computational strategies, and orchestrate them to form and test hypotheses by typically integrating heterogeneous sources of data. Our field has made remarkable strides towards a better understanding of microbial ecology and evolution thanks to the insights afforded by big data. However, dealing with complex datasets brings its own challenges that can also lead to various undesirable outcomes that span from underutilization of data to overinterpretation of findings. Our session aims to bring together experts of computation and microbial ecology to demonstrate applications of integrated ‘omics strategies to address contemporary questions of microbiology, and foster a dialogue between the speakers and attendees through best practices in data analysis, integration, and interpretation.

title: Bridging Disciplines with Microbiology: The Case of Microbially Influenced Corrosion
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Federico Lauro, Singapore
Microbially Influenced Corrosion (MIC) represents a significant degradation mechanism affecting a diverse array of materials in environments where microorganisms exist. Accounting for approximately 20% of all corrosion-related incidents, MIC poses substantial financial costs and risks to the integrity of vital infrastructure. Despite being recognized for over 50 years, many essential aspects of MIC remain elusive. Its likelihood, mechanism, and rate are influenced by an intricate interplay of microbiological, chemical, and metallurgical factors. Consequently, comprehending MIC's mechanisms, confirming its presence, and developing mitigation strategies necessitates a multidisciplinary approach.
In this roundtable, we will encourage participants to engage in a dynamic exchange with experts from various fields, including chemistry, microbial ecology, engineering, and materials science, to share their experiences with MIC. This will foster a holistic understanding and collaborative problem-solving approach, thereby advancing microbiology's role as the interdisciplinary bond that unites a range of scientific fields.

title: Microbiome 2.0: Intraspecific-level interactions and the campaign for higher resolution
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Lu Fan, China
Since the invention of microscopy and the birth of microbiology, the advance in our ability to see ‘smaller’ has been always promoting the breakthroughs in microbial research. Today, microscopy has reached the resolution level of atoms, while spatially and temporally continuing imaging has made the interactions inside and between cells vivid.

The birth and growth of the microbiome study, for comparison, has been companied by our intention to think ‘bigger’ – to disentangle the complex microbial interactions in a pinch of earth to the entire earth planet. Driven mainly by innovations in nucleic acid sequencing and bioinformatic technologies, we can now easily identify the composition of microorganisms in a community, their potential ecological functions, and putative interactions, all at once and all in situ.

So, what is next? An emerging tendency in microbiome study is again, to think and see ‘smaller’. As a microbiome is basically a collection of interacting cells and viruses, finer-scale approaches need to capture the genetic and functional heterogeneity of these components. For example, can we ultimately elucidate the taxonomic identity of each microbial cell or viral particle in a microbiome? And can we distinguish the behaviors of different E. coli cells in your gut and in all our guts spatially and temporally? – All such demands demand one thing: analytical technologies with higher and higher resolutions in microbial identity.

In this roundtable, recent progress in technologies to resolve intraspecific features of microorganisms will be reviewed and recent discoveries in intraspecific ecology of microbiomes will be discussed.

title: So nice when used twice: synthesis gaps and opportunities in microbial ecology. Democratizing microbial ecology through global research: Shared resources and equity
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Stephanie Jurburg, Germany
In the midst of a looming global biodiversity crisis, approaches to rapidly collect,
curate, catalog, and integrate biodiversity data at global scales is more important than ever
before. Historically, data collection and reuse have been related with local access to funding for
scientific research and infrastructure, generating blindspots in the distribution of biodiversity
data. At the same time, areas with limited access to research funding, where biodiversity data is
generated at a slower pace can benefit from data reuse to reinterpret extant data within novel
contexts or at different scales in order to further the local development of excellent research. This
is especially true for sequence-based biodiversity research, which can be prohibitively expensive,
but is essential to detecting and cataloging microbial diversity. This roundtable will explore
current initiatives for exploring global microbial diversity that directly consider the equitability
of data generation and data reuse. Our panelists will present their own experiences with large
scale microbiome data collection and synthesis research, highlight the importance of capacity
building, and discuss the outcomes of the Datathon initiative, a 3-day microbiome reuse event
which took place in Latin America in 2023, and which will be organized for Africa in
2024-2025.

title: Microbial solutions to CO2 capture in the ocean- what ocean negative carbon emissions can accomplish?
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Nianzhi Jiao, China
Microbes in the ocean play fundamental roles in CO2 emission into or uptake from the atmosphere. The Global Ocean Negative Carbon Emission (Global ONCE) Program supported by the United Nations Ocean Decade aims to harvest the power of ocean microbes to enhance CO2 uptake using natural or eco-engineering approaches. In this context, we advocate various ocean negative carbon emission practices, highlighting three examples: 1) ocean negative carbon emission via land-ocean integration, 2) integrated mechanisms for carbon sequestration in sea-farming fields, and 3) ocean alkalinity enhancement (OAE) through management of coastal wastewater treatment plants. To ensure transparency among the ocean research community, governmental officials and stakeholders, the Global ONCE Program emphasizes the responsible consideration of potential outcomes from these eco-engineering practices. We also advocate a code of conduct that can be continuously updated to ensure prudent implementation of emerging ocean negative carbon emission technologies, aligning with the acceptability and feasibility standards of the research community and the public. We invite the ISME community to support, engage with, or supervise the Global ONCE campaign, striving for a sustainable ocean future beyond the UN Ocean Decade.

title: Microbial ecology and climate change: a call to action
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Lisa Stein, Canada
Microbes and their viruses are key players in climate homeostasis: they control greenhouse gas emissions, provide basic ecosystem functions, enable plant and animal adaptation and survival, contribute to crop productivity, and have many other vital roles. Rapid climate change is altering microbial communities and their functions from molecular to ecosystem levels, changing rates and fluxes in biogeochemical cycles, and affecting interactions between microbes and their host systems. Due to the importance and significance of microorganisms to planetary and lifeform function, it is essential that they are considered in the global discourse on climate change effects, adaptation, and mitigation. Yet, neither IPCC reports nor international COP meetings include microorganisms or microbiologists as a regular part of the climate conversation. This roundtable features research perspectives from climate change microbiologists from around the world to address how microbes and their viruses are affected by and are affecting climate change, opportunities on how we as a society can leverage our knowledge for climate change adaptation and mitigation, and ways that our global collective of microbial ecologists can be recognized and heard in critical climate conversations.

title: SeqCode – up, running and necessary
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Maria Chuvochina, Australia
Officially introduced in 2022, the SeqCode and its Registry have been operating for more than a year. With the main goal of providing a stable and standardised way of naming uncultured taxa, the SeqCode Registry has received more than 900 submissions, resulting in the valid publication of more than 200 names. During this period, the Registry has undergone considerable development, including the expansion of automatic checks, the addition of batch submissions, and improved curation aid. In this roundtable, we seek to reflect on achievements and challenges of SeqCode operation since its official launch. We will also discuss future improvements to further engage our microbial ecological community. Ongoing debates about the scope of SeqCode and nomenclatural status of names published under this code have led to proposals to amend the International Code of Nomenclature of Prokaryotes (ICNP) to regulate Candidatus names analogously to validly published names of cultured taxa. We will discuss the implications of this and whether an alternative proposal to amend the ICNP which would reciprocally recognise names that are validly published under the SeqCode would be a better solution.

title: Synthetic microbial ecology for theory testing and applications
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Zhili He, China
Chair: Ruiwen Hu, United States
Microbial communities have seemingly limitless capabilities, such as driving biogeochemical cycles, increasing crop productivity, mediating food fermentation, recovering valuable resources, and sustaining human and environmental health. Current sequencing technologies and culturomics have provided novel insights into our understanding of the diversity, function, dynamics, interaction and evolution of microbial communities in diverse ecosystems. However, due to the complexity of natural microbial communities and uncontrollable environments, our understanding of fundamental principles governing microbial communities and subsequently engineering of microbial communities remain challenging. Recently, synthetic microbial ecology has been developed to address such challenges via its reduced complexity and enhanced controllability. This Roundtable aims to update the current status of synthetic microbial ecology theories and methods, highlight key findings in the synthetic microbial community study, identify challenges and problems, and then propose feasible solutions. This Roundtable will greatly promote collaboration within the scientific community of synthetic microbial ecology and beyond. During this Roundtable, we are especially interested in general principles and rules that govern microbial community behaviors, microbially-driven biogeochemical processes and their potential coupling mechanisms, and syntheses of community-level traits towards engineering microbiomes. We anticipate the Roundtable to be of broad interest across the field of microbial ecology and promote novel synergies and collaborations.

title: Microbial production of “dark oxygen”: An overlooked process in Earth’s hidden ecosystems
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: S. Emil Ruff, United States
Microbial metabolic pathways and ecological niches are often defined and characterized by rather binary distributions of light (illuminated vs dark) and oxygen (oxic vs anoxic). For example, biological oxygen production is commonly associated with illuminated oxic zones. However, the exploration of remote areas and the development of high-resolution sampling tools and analyses led to the discovery of systems that produce oxygen in conditions of apparent anoxia and permanent darkness. The latter process was dubbed “dark oxygen production” (DOP) and can proceed via abiotic chemical reactions or via microbial dismutation of chlorite or nitric oxide—metabolisms fundamentally different from photosynthesis. Recent work suggests that microbial DOP is widespread in groundwater ecosystems, deep rock fractures, subsurface sediments and other ecosystems that are thought to be devoid of oxygen. The pathways necessary for DOP are found in many lineages across the tree of life, including diverse Bacteroidota, globally important marine archaea Nitrosopumilus maritimus, and the widely used model organism Pseudomonas aeruginosa. In hindsight, there are numerous accounts of oxygen anomalies in groundwater, as well as evidence for the activity of strict aerobes in apparently anoxic habitats, which may be explained by this overlooked process. The production and availability of molecular oxygen in dark ecosystems fundamentally changes our understanding of the evolution and functioning of Earth’s subsurface and has implications for global chemical cycles. We invite ISME participants to discuss with a panel of experts whether microbial DOP could be a globally relevant process in apparently anoxic environments, where DOP may occur, how we can study it, which microbes and metabolisms may be involved, whether DOP impacts global element cycles and whether it may have influenced the evolution of the geobiosphere.

title: Global biogeochemical cycling: Microbes supporting ecosystem services
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Marcela Hernández, United Kingdom
Convenor: Belinda Ferrari, Australia
Microbes play an essential role in driving biogeochemical cycles, making them crucial for supporting ecosystem services and life on Earth. This session will focus on the microbiology of key cycles, including carbon, nitrogen, sulfur metabolism, and the microbes capable of producing and/or consuming trace gases. The talks will cover some of the most recent advances and cutting-edge methods used to study the underlying principles of complex microbial biogeochemistry spanning a wide range of environments, including marine, agricultural, polar regions, caves, and volcanoes.

title: New microbial physiologies and metabolic capacities
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Marla Trindade, South Africa
Chair: Susumu Yoshizawa, Japan
Given that microbial metabolism and metabolic versatility underpins all aspects of microbial ecology, this session offers a chocolate-box assortment of topics and discoveries, something for everyone and touches on aspects covered by most all other sessions. The selected speaker and poster presentations bring the most recent discoveries that challenge current models of greenhouse gas emissions, revise our understanding of nitrogen cycling, shed new light on species survival in oxygen-depleted environments, expand our understanding of parasite life cycles, reveal a previously unknown link between carbon and nitrogen cycles, offer promising bioremediation strategies and sustainable bioplastic manufacturing and so much more. This session demonstrates how technological advancements have expanded our knowledge of microbial physiology that deepens our understanding of microbial evolution and ecological roles but have also paved the way for innovative applications in biotechnology, environmental science, and medicine. It has a bit of everything and promises to inspire new research initiatives.

title: Freshwater microbial ecology in built and natural environments
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Jana Milucka, Germany
Chair: Sanjay Swarup, Singapore
Freshwater ecosystems provide key services to human society and are central to the global water cycle. Their high vulnerability to climate change requires urgent effort in understanding the role of microorganisms in freshwater ecosystem functioning.
This session aims to bring together presentations describing taxonomic and functional microbial diversity, ecological processes, microbial role in biogeochemical transformations of carbon, nutrients and trace gases, as well as community structure and interactions in various freshwater environments. These include but are not limited to natural systems such as lakes, ponds, rivers, wetlands and groundwater, and urban systems such as reservoirs, waterways, and catchments. Contributions aiming at understanding microbial response to ecosystem alteration and recovery (e.g. changing water quality due to pollution and warming) are welcome.

title: Integrating equity into microbiome science from crops to communities
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Sue Ishaq, United States
Chair: Adolphe Zeze, Côte d'Ivoire
Microorganisms are critical to many aspects of biological life, and the collective microbial community, or microbiome, can be impacted by environmental factors which may be driven by social, economic, medical, or political constraints that restrict available choices and may impact our health. This session explores the way that microbes connect to social disparities, and how microbial ecology can be used to benefit public health and vulnerable populations.

title: New microbial physiologies and metabolic capacities
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Marla Trindade, South Africa
Chair: Susumu Yoshizawa, Japan
Given that microbial metabolism and metabolic versatility underpins all aspects of microbial ecology, this session offers a chocolate-box assortment of topics and discoveries, something for everyone and touches on aspects covered by most all other sessions. The selected speaker and poster presentations bring the most recent discoveries that challenge current models of greenhouse gas emissions, revise our understanding of nitrogen cycling, shed new light on species survival in oxygen-depleted environments, expand our understanding of parasite life cycles, reveal a previously unknown link between carbon and nitrogen cycles, offer promising bioremediation strategies and sustainable bioplastic manufacturing and so much more. This session demonstrates how technological advancements have expanded our knowledge of microbial physiology that deepens our understanding of microbial evolution and ecological roles but have also paved the way for innovative applications in biotechnology, environmental science, and medicine. It has a bit of everything and promises to inspire new research initiatives.

title: Global biogeochemical cycling: Microbes supporting ecosystem services
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Belinda Ferrari, Australia
Convenor: Marcela Hernández, United Kingdom
Microbes play an essential role in driving biogeochemical cycles, making them crucial for supporting ecosystem services and life on Earth. This session will focus on the microbiology of key cycles, including carbon, nitrogen, sulfur metabolism, and the microbes capable of producing and/or consuming trace gases. The talks will cover some of the most recent advances and cutting-edge methods used to study the underlying principles of complex microbial biogeochemistry spanning a wide range of environments, including marine, agricultural, polar regions, caves, and volcanoes.

session-info-text: Session Leaders Chair:  Jana Milucka, Germany Chair:  Sanjay Swarup, Singapore Freshwater ecosystems provide key services to human society and are central to the global water cycle. Their high vulnerability to climate change requires urgent effort in understanding the role of microorganisms in freshwater ecosystem functioning. This session aims to bring together presentations describing taxonomic and functional microbial diversity, ecological processes, microbial role in biogeochemical transformations of carbon, nutrients and trace gases, as well as community structure and interactions in various freshwater environments. These include but are not limited to natural systems such as lakes, ponds, rivers, wetlands and groundwater, and urban systems such as reservoirs, waterways, and catchments. Contributions aiming at understanding microbial response to ecosystem alteration and recovery (e.g. changing water quality due to pollution and warming) are welcome. title: Microbes and Climate Change
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Thulani Makhalanyane, South Africa
The Microbes and Climate Change event hosted by the International Society for Microbial Ecology (ISME) and the Centre for Epidemic Response and Innovation (CERI) at Stellenbosch University, will explore the critical role of microbes including bacteria, fungi, protists and viruses and the potential effect of climate change on their diversity and function. The speakers will further highlight the potential feedback that microbial communities may exert on climate change across different ecosystems including marine, terrestrial and human microbiomes. The short presentations will be followed by a mediated panel discussion highlighting potential strategies for environmental stewardship.

title: Microbial ecology of the built environment
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Patrick Lee, Hong Kong
Chair: Stephan Schuster, Singapore
The biological composition of aerosols has various sources that have significant impacts to atmospheric processes as well as human and environmental health. New ways of studying this and latest technologies continually help us understand this unique microbiome. These studies have highlighted the dynamic nature of microbial diversity found across various temporal and spatial scales, from different types of indoor/outdoor built environments and how it affects health. This session welcomes contributors on topics related to but not limited to microbiome in built environments, indoor/outdoor systems, aerobiology and health.

title: Axes of microbial ecology and climate change: progress and priorities
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Sunil Mundra, United Arab Emirates
Chair: Virginia Rich, United States
This session will highlight the cutting edge in global change microbiology research and translation, across a broad range of habitats, and including One Health for plants, animals and humans. We will hear how microbes can amplify or dampen climate change impacts via mechanisms such as carbon stabilization, pollution mitigation, and holobiont-mitigated stress tolerance. Participants will come away with new insights into the innovation and urgency in this dynamic area of microbial ecology. Join us in charting microbial roles in the trajectory of our changing planet, and approaches for enlisting these tiny but mighty allies in the challenging time ahead.

title: Context is key: ecological, evolutionary, and environmental determinants of niche plasticity
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Sean Gibbons, United States
Chair: Kim Handley, New Zealand
What factors govern the habitat or resource preference plasticity of specific microorganisms during community assembly? This session will consider evolutionary, ecological, physical or chemical factors that influence microbial niche choice in natural or experimental systems. Examples of topics covered include, genetic and physiological adaptations enabling niche expansion or differentiation, effects of niche selection on the physiological or genomic attributes of microbial cells, and the effects of microbial interactions on community structure and function.

title: Ecology and functionality at the microbial/plant interface
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Lucy Moleleki, South Africa
Convenor: Daniele Daffonchio, Saudi Arabia
Convenor: Lucy Moleleki, South Africa
The recent advancements in understanding interactions of microorganisms in all ecosystems are revealing the prominent role of microbial communities in the biology and ecology of plants as well as the complexity of the organismal interactions. The microbial-plant interface is increasingly studied for deciphering the role of microbes in the ecology and functioning of the plant metaorganism with great potential for applications in the management of plant health and agriculture crop productivity and sustainability. In this session the ecology of microbial communities associated to plants and their functional properties are discussed with focus on the interactions among pathogens and plants as well as on plant growth promoters capable of alleviating stresses and providing services to the plant hosts and the plant/soil ecosystem.

title: Diversity in STEM Panel
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Ashley Dungan, Australia
STEM fields, especially ecology and biology that our field of microbial ecology sits in, are entrenched in racism, colonialism, sexism, ableism, etc. that creates a highly exclusive system (Cronin et al. 2021; Trisos et al. 2021). Racism and colonialism are ecological issues and working to create a more inclusive environment is a value of the International Society of Microbial Ecology.

The ISME Early Career Scientist Committee is hosting a panel session to give a voice to a diverse range of scientists. This includes queer and transgender scientists, disabled scientists, neurodiverse scientists, first-generation scientists, scientists from low socio-economic backgrounds, and/or scientists of marginalized race or ethnicity, noting that people can have intersecting identities with compounding effects.
Our goal is to discuss the challenges that these scientists face as a means to explore the ways that our community can prevent the disparities in career outcomes and opportunities that are too often associated with systematically marginalized scientists. We encourage attendance and participation by all ISME19 attendees, but particularly those in senior leadership roles or who supervise students and staff.
Show More

title: Microbial ecology of the built environment
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Patrick Lee, Hong Kong
Chair: Stephan Schuster, Singapore
The biological composition of aerosols has various sources that have significant impacts to atmospheric processes as well as human and environmental health. New ways of studying this and latest technologies continually help us understand this unique microbiome. These studies have highlighted the dynamic nature of microbial diversity found across various temporal and spatial scales, from different types of indoor/outdoor built environments and how it affects health. This session welcomes contributors on topics related to but not limited to microbiome in built environments, indoor/outdoor systems, aerobiology and health.

title: Axes of microbial ecology and climate change: progress and priorities
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Sunil Mundra, United Arab Emirates
Chair: Virginia Rich, United States
This session will highlight the cutting edge in global change microbiology research and translation, across a broad range of habitats, and including One Health for plants, animals and humans. We will hear how microbes can amplify or dampen climate change impacts via mechanisms such as carbon stabilization, pollution mitigation, and holobiont-mitigated stress tolerance. Participants will come away with new insights into the innovation and urgency in this dynamic area of microbial ecology. Join us in charting microbial roles in the trajectory of our changing planet, and approaches for enlisting these tiny but mighty allies in the challenging time ahead.

title: Context is key: ecological, evolutionary, and environmental determinants of niche plasticity
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Sean Gibbons, United States
Convenor: Kim Handley, New Zealand
What factors govern the habitat or resource preference plasticity of specific microorganisms during community assembly? This session will consider evolutionary, ecological, physical or chemical factors that influence microbial niche choice in natural or experimental systems. Examples of topics covered include, genetic and physiological adaptations enabling niche expansion or differentiation, effects of niche selection on the physiological or genomic attributes of microbial cells, and the effects of microbial interactions on community structure and function.

title: Alma Dal Co Award Presentation - Jean-Baptiste Raina
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Nicole Dubilier, Germany
Jean-Baptiste Raina, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia, is the winner of the Alma Dal Co Award 2024, recognizing his significant contribution to microbial ecology in marine environments.

Jean-Baptiste Raina is a pioneering marine microbial ecologist whose innovative approach has significantly advanced the field of Microbial Ecology. By integrating environmental microbiology, chemical ecology, and biophysics, JB Raina has overcome technical challenges to uncover crucial microbial interactions in marine environments. His work has led to major breakthroughs and new methodologies which have been widely adopted in the ISME community.

Some of his key contributions include the development of in situ chemotaxis assay, a groundbreaking platform enabling the study of microbial behavior directly in the ocean; Micro-volume DNA Extraction, a technique that accurately characterizes microbial communities from minimal seawater samples and; Single-cell Nutrient Exchange Quantification, providing detailed insights into microbial interactions at the cellular level.

JB Raina has also heavily contributed to our understanding of the marine sulfur cycle, discovering the first non-photosynthetic DMSP producer and identifying genes involved in DMSP production and degradation. His recent research challenges long-standing beliefs about bacterial swimming behavior, highlighting his role as a transformative figure in marine microbial ecology.
Show More

title: Ecology and functionality at the microbial/plant interface
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Monica Höfte, Belgium
Convenor: Daniele Daffonchio, Saudi Arabia
Convenor: Lucy Moleleki, South Africa
The recent advancements in understanding interactions of microorganisms in all ecosystems are revealing the prominent role of microbial communities in the biology and ecology of plants as well as the complexity of the organismal interactions. The microbial-plant interface is increasingly studied for deciphering the role of microbes in the ecology and functioning of the plant metaorganism with great potential for applications in the management of plant health and agriculture crop productivity and sustainability. In this session the ecology of microbial communities associated to plants and their functional properties are discussed with focus on the interactions among pathogens and plants as well as on plant growth promoters capable of alleviating stresses and providing services to the plant hosts and the plant/soil ecosystem.

title: Microbial ecology of Anti-Microbial Resistance
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Daniel Read, United Kingdom
Chair: Yong-Guan Zhu, China
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) poses an ever-growing threat to the health and well-being of society. The role of microbial ecology is emerging as a crucial field in the understanding of AMR dynamics and evolution. This session focuses on the ecological dimensions of AMR, where cutting-edge omic, culturing, and computational methods converge to explore resistance dissemination and evolution. This session aims to bring together presentations that reveal genetic reservoirs, transmission dynamics, and adaptive strategies of microbial communities under antimicrobial stress, across ecosystems, from clinical settings to the environment. The session welcomes contributors with an interdisciplinary focus, uniting computational biology, microbial ecology, environmental and clinical microbiology.

title: Global and continental biogeography
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Jim Ji-Zheng He, Australia
Chair: Weidong Kong, China
Microbial biogeography is scale dependent. The study of microbial biogeography at global and continental scales is fundamental, as it can provide large-scale microbial distribution patterns and the underpinning ecological principles that govern the patterns and their successionsacross diverse environments. This biogeographical information helps microbial ecologists to build predictive distribution maps of microorganisms and paves the way for forecasting the ecological consequences of ongoing environmental changes at global and continental scales. There is an urgent need to linking the global distribution patterns of microbial diversity, community structure, and functions with physicochemical parameters and elucidating the ecological principles at large scales. The feasibility of such large-scale investigations has been greatly enhanced by the reduced sequencing cost, advances in sequencing technology, and improvement in bioinformatics. This session will gather the latest scientific advances on the global and continental distribution patterns of microbial communities and discuss the future directions and collaborations in the field.

title: New approaches to old diseases
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Herbert Itabangi, Uganda
Chair: Grant Theron, South Africa
This session showcases cutting-edge research in microbiome science and microbial genetics, emphasizing their diverse applications in health and environmental monitoring. Key themes include the development of microbiome-based therapies, innovative models for studying infections and non-communicable diseases, advanced genetic methods to study microbial life and antimicrobial mechanisms, and environmental and epidemiological surveillance for tracking disease dynamics. This sessions aims to underscores the transformative potential of microbiome science in developing new therapies and enhancing disease monitoring.

title: Microbial ecology of Anti-Microbial Resistance
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Daniel Read, United Kingdom
Chair: Yong-Guan Zhu, China
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) poses an ever-growing threat to the health and well-being of society. The role of microbial ecology is emerging as a crucial field in the understanding of AMR dynamics and evolution. This session focuses on the ecological dimensions of AMR, where cutting-edge omic, culturing, and computational methods converge to explore resistance dissemination and evolution. This session aims to bring together presentations that reveal genetic reservoirs, transmission dynamics, and adaptive strategies of microbial communities under antimicrobial stress, across ecosystems, from clinical settings to the environment. The session welcomes contributors with an interdisciplinary focus, uniting computational biology, microbial ecology, environmental and clinical microbiology.

title: Global and continental biogeography
session-info:
Session Leaders
Chair: Jim Ji-Zheng He, Australia
Chair: Weidong Kong, China
Microbial biogeography is scale dependent. The study of microbial biogeography at global and continental scales is fundamental, as it can provide large-scale microbial distribution patterns and the underpinning ecological principles that govern the patterns and their successionsacross diverse environments. This biogeographical information helps microbial ecologists to build predictive distribution maps of microorganisms and paves the way for forecasting the ecological consequences of ongoing environmental changes at global and continental scales. There is an urgent need to linking the global distribution patterns of microbial diversity, community structure, and functions with physicochemical parameters and elucidating the ecological principles at large scales. The feasibility of such large-scale investigations has been greatly enhanced by the reduced sequencing cost, advances in sequencing technology, and improvement in bioinformatics. This session will gather the latest scientific advances on the global and continental distribution patterns of microbial communities and discuss the future directions and collaborations in the field.
